author: By A.O. Scott
title: What Donald Trump Didn’t Say After His Trial
description: In his post-verdict remarks, the former president sounded more like an aggrieved New York businessman than the political martyr his supporters believe him to be.
content: The way to evaluate a political speech — I mean as a literary critic, not as a pundit or a partisan — is to examine how the rhetoric rises to the occasion. Does the moment demand gravity or transcendence? Humility or defiance? Do the speaker’s words answer the call of history?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Carrasquero, Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Why Mexico May Elect a Female President Before the United States
description: Having a woman as president will be a milestone in a country where gender-based violence is so common. But how much will change remains unclear.
content: Mexico is poised to elect its first female president on Sunday, a historic leap in a country long known for its machismo — and a big moment for all of North America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: After Biden’s Push for Truce, Netanyahu Calls Israel’s War Plans Unchanged
description: The timing of the remarks seemed to rebuff the president’s hopes for a speedy end to the war. But some analysts said the prime minister was aiming at domestic supporters, not the White House.
content: A day after President Biden called on Israel and Hamas to reach a truce, declaring that it was “time for this war to end,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Saturday reiterated that Israel would not agree to a permanent cease-fire in Gaza as long as Hamas still retains governing and military power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Sergey Ponomarev
title: In the West Bank, Guns and a Locked Gate Signal a Town’s New Residents
description: Since the war in Gaza began, armed Israeli settlers, often accompanied by the army, have stepped up seizures of land long used by Palestinians.
content: From the outskirts of his town in the West Bank, the mayor surveyed the rocky hills stretching toward the Dead Sea where Palestinians had long farmed and herded, and pointed out the new features of the landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: How Michael Rainey Jr. of ‘Power Book II: Ghost’ Spends His Sundays
description: Mr. Rainey starts his day with tea, and then it’s time for fancy cars, making beats and Call of Duty with his friends.
content: Michael Rainey Jr. had looked up to the rapper 50 Cent since he was 8 years old. So when he landed the opportunity to work with him (real name: Curtis James Jackson III) on the Starz crime drama “Power,” he couldn’t have been more excited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Idaho Man in ‘Doomsday’ Killings Is Sentenced to Death
description: Chad Daybell was convicted on Thursday in the murders of his first wife and two children of his current spouse, Lori Vallow Daybell. The couple’s extreme beliefs drew attention to the case.
content: An Idaho judge on Saturday sentenced a man to death, two days after he was found guilty of first-degree murder and other charges in the 2019 killings of his first wife and two of his current wife’s children, capping a case that drew scrutiny because of the couple’s “doomsday” religious beliefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Florida Deputy Who Fatally Shot Airman Is Fired
description: The Okaloosa County Sheriff’s Office said that the use of deadly force during the May 3 encounter at the airman’s apartment was unreasonable.
content: The Florida sheriff’s deputy who fatally shot a U.S. Air Force senior airman in the airman’s home this month has been fired, the sheriff’s office said on Friday, describing the deputy’s use of deadly force, which was captured on body camera, as “not objectively reasonable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman, Kellen Browning and Maya King
title: Trump Verdict Hardens Many Views, but Changes Some, Too
description: For the remaining undecided voters, the decision to pick former President Donald J. Trump could be more difficult now that he is a felon.
content: As the nation’s electorate processed the felony convictions of Donald J. Trump, the partisan divide in the verdict’s wake did not look so much like opposing sides of a chasm but like two alternate universes, one where the former president had been hounded and persecuted by his corrupt political enemies, the other where justice had finally been served to a career criminal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Friend Asked for Clothing Donations and Then Sold Them on Poshmark. Do I Confront Her?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to handle deception by a friend.
content: My friend is a high school teacher in a low-income area. She always shares tearful stories of her students’ need for food, school supplies, professional clothes for job interviews and so on. Over the years, I’ve donated food, snacks and clothing for her to give to her students. A few months ago, my friend said there was a job fair coming up at the school and the students needed clothes; she would take anything we could donate. I went through my closet and gathered professional blazers, skirts, pants and blouses and gave them to her. Long story short: I decided to start an account on Poshmark to sell my family’s old clothes. When I looked up some of my friends’ closets on the site, I discovered my teacher friend had posted and sold all the items I gave her for her students! Not just one or two items — all 20! What’s the right thing to do? Do I confront her, or do I ignore the fact that those kids never got the donated items? Once a donation has been made, what is the ethical expectation? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: U Tin Oo, Embattled Pro-Democracy Leader in Myanmar, Dies at 97
description: Once one of his country’s most powerful figures, he helped found its main opposition party. “I had to face up to the harm I did to people when I served in the army,” he said.
content: U Tin Oo, a former Burmese armed forces chief and minister of defense who turned against his country’s repressive government to become a leader of the pro-democracy movement there, died on Saturday in Yangon, Myanmar. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Typecasting
description: Luke W. Schreiber’s debut Sunday puzzle is full of character(s).
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isobel Lewis
title: ‘Doctor Who’ Episode 5 Recap: Bursting the Bubble
description: The Doctor saves a rich wannabe vlogger from being eaten by a giant slug, but a final twist leaves him reeling.
content: We’ve passed the midway point in this season of “Doctor Who,” and the show’s ambition shows no sign of subsiding. After playing with themes of religion and politics, it’s artificial intelligence, already touched on in the earlier episode “Boom,” that’s the topic du jour in “Dot and Bubble.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Sarah Kessler and Ephrat Livni
title: Companies Counter Pushback on Price Increases With Promotions
description: “The consumer was a fat pig — now there’s nothing left, and they need to feed the pig again,” one banker told DealBook.
content: The president of McDonald’s USA, Joe Erlinger, pushed back on “inaccurate” reports this week that said the chain had more than doubled its prices on some items over the last decade. But his retort wasn’t exactly reassuring: The average price of a Big Mac is up 21 percent from 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cram In
description: Eric Warren’s Saturday debut fits a lot of fun into tight spaces.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Eric Warren’s second puzzle for The New York Times after his Friday debut in March 2023, and I think the two grids are at about the same level of difficulty. They have a similarly low word count, which is challenging for both the creator and the solver. Today we have only 66 clues, most of which lead to longer entries presented in stacks and stairs. This configuration looks imposing, but there are mild entries that made it solve quite smoothly for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Holy Cow, 34 for 45!
description: But the real verdict comes on 11/5.
content: WASHINGTON — At Nativity grade school, we grew up steeped in the lore — and gore — of martyrs. For their brave deeds and words, these men and women were stoned, crucified, beheaded, stripped of all their skin, shot with arrows and cooked alive on a red-hot griddle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: The Wedding Singer Takes a Celebrity Turn
description: To delight their guests, couples are booking musical headliners to give surprise performances at their weddings.
content: Wendy Mazur said her “jaw hit the floor” when she saw her favorite pop singer, Goldford, walk out with his guitar during her first dance with Jerry Bedwell at their wedding in April 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: ‘He’s Had Great Challenges’: Giuliani Holds 80th Birthday Amid Many Woes
description: The indicted and increasingly isolated former New York mayor celebrated his birthday over pasta and meatballs. Donald J. Trump sent a video.
content: Consider this Midtown split screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russian Missiles Hit Ukraine’s Energy System, Again
description: The large-scale air assault struck several sites in western Ukraine, including places near the borders with NATO member countries.
content: Russian forces struck several of Ukraine’s energy facilities with drones and missiles early Saturday, in a major air assault that targeted cities across the country, including some near the borders with NATO members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 357, June 2, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Champions League’s Most Bitter Rivalry May Be Off the Field
description: No club has won European soccer’s richest prize more than Real Madrid, but its recent dominance has been accompanied by a bruising fight over the tournament’s future.
content: Real Madrid had the celebratory jerseys ready as soon as its place in the Champions League final was secured. As the players raced to one another, exulting in yet another heart-stopping, nerve-shredding win, staff members sprinted onto the field after them, ensuring each star was correctly attired.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Laborers Who Take Time Off in Pakistan’s Record Heat Risk Going Hungry
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 2, 2024.
content: “This isn’t heat. It’s a punishment, maybe from God.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Warnings of Election Meddling by China Never Reached the Prime Minister
description: A watchdog agency found roadblocks to the flow of information both within the spy agency and the public service.
content: It can be a bit difficult to keep tabs on the various inquiries and examinations into foreign interference in Canadian elections, particularly by China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Robert Pickton, Notorious Canadian Serial Killer, Dies at 74
description: Convicted in the murder of six women (though he boasted of killing many more), he died of unspecified injuries after being assaulted in prison.
content: Robert Pickton, one of Canada’s most notorious serial killers, whose crimes called attention to police and societal disregard for the violent deaths of Indigenous women, died on Friday after a fellow inmate attacked him in prison in Quebec, where he was serving a life sentence. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mixed News About Opioid Overdoses
description: Readers discuss reports of a decline in deaths in the U.S. but a rise in Baltimore.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: How to Think Through the Moral Tangle in Gaza
description: It’s not a black-and-white morality tale.
content: I’ve been on a book tour for the last few weeks, speaking around the country, and one of the questions I get asked most often isn’t about my book at all but along the lines of: What should I think of the war in Gaza?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Hiroko Masuike
title: The 7 Grueling Months to Reclaim the Bookstore Dream a Fire Stole
description: A fire left Lucy Yu’s literary hub in Chinatown gutted. She was determined to rebuild it.
content: Lucy Yu wasn’t sure if she had smoke in her lungs or was having an anxiety attack. She needed fresh air.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books to Help You Go Gray Gracefully
description: Ditch the dye; live with style.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Very Online Afterlife of Franz Kafka
description: One hundred years after his death, the Czech writer circulates as a pop idol of digital alienation.
content: On TikTok, a collection of objects sits atop a stack of books: a string of pearls, a Diptyque candle, a Sylvanian Families rabbit figurine in a scallop-collared dress. A woman’s hand brushes them aside. She pages through the pile of books below. We see “My Year of Rest and Relaxation” by Ottessa Moshfegh and “The Bell Jar” by Sylvia Plath. Also, “The Metamorphosis” by Franz Kafka, a fat black bug on its cover. A question typed over the scene asks: What do you conclude about me?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dessler
title: Oil and Gas Companies Are Trying to Rig the Marketplace
description: Fossil fuel interests are spreading misinformation that renewable energy is harmful, unreliable and worse for consumers.
content: Many of us focused on the problem of climate change have been waiting for the day when renewable energy would become cheaper than fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Democrats Push Biden to Make Trump’s Felonies a Top 2024 Issue
description: Interviews with dozens of Democrats reveal a party hungry to tell voters that Donald Trump’s conviction makes him unfit for office, and hopeful that President Biden will lead the way.
content: Now that former President Donald J. Trump is a convicted criminal, the Democratic Party finds itself wrestling with a choice that will help define this year’s presidential race: Should it try to push his felonies to the center of the election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, AMC+, Disney+, Hulu, and More in June
description: “The Boys,” “Orphan Black: Echoes,” “The Bear” and “The Acolyte” will be streaming.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of June’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: It’s June Again
description: Summer returns, and with it all the feelings and fantasies and fears we associate with the season.
content: June! Again! I know! Where has the time gone? It’s boring to even raise the issue — your subjective experience of the months and years passing so quickly, how it seems just yesterday you were doing something (making plans to see Barbenheimer, maybe? That was last summer!) and now here we are, doing this again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Barrett
title: An Epidemic Hit These Farms Hard. Then Things Got Even Darker.
description: Scott Preston’s debut novel, “The Borrowed Hills,” unfolds during the 2001 outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Britain.
content: Scott Preston’s debut novel, “The Borrowed Hills,” begins in the north of England during the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in 2001, when several million British farm animals were slaughtered to contain the deadly virus. Steve Elliman, a truck driver, has returned to his father’s sheep farm in the hilly, rainy, boulder-strewn region of Cumbria, also known as the fells. The Ellimans are tenant farmers, unlike their more successful neighbor, William Herne, who owns the land on which he grazes his much larger flock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Yael Dayan, Israeli Writer, Politician and Daughter of War Hero, Dies at 85
description: She was hailed for her books and admired for promoting women’s rights. But her support for a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict angered many.
content: Yael Dayan, a celebrated Israeli writer who, after the death of her father, the war hero and statesman Moshe Dayan, entered politics and became a proponent of women’s rights, L.G.B.T.Q. issues and a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict, died on May 18 at her home in Tel Aviv. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: South Africa Is Not a Metaphor
description: The country’s story of liberation has been both a symbol of hope and a burden. Now it’s time for reality.
content: If you want to understand why the party that liberated South Africa from white rule lost its parliamentary majority in the election this week, you need to look no further than Beauty Mzingeli’s living room. The first time she cast a ballot, she could hardly sleep the night before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Liubov Sholudko and Tyler Hicks
title: She’s 98, and Walked Past Corpses to Escape Russian Attacks
description: “If only everything would stop,” said Lidiia Lomikovska, who walked to safety after her town was attacked. But for civilians in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, it is not stopping.
content: When a Russian soldier appeared outside 98-year-old Lidiia Lomikovska’s shattered home in eastern Ukraine in late April, the first thing he did was shoot and kill the family dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: A Small Army Combating a Flood of Deepfakes in India’s Election
description: Social media is awash with A.I.-altered audio, clipped video and manipulated images. Fact-checkers want to save the public from deception.
content: Through the middle of a high-stakes election being held during a mind-melting heat wave, a blizzard of confusing deepfakes blows across India. The variety seems endless: A.I.-powered mimicry, ventriloquy and deceptive editing effects. Some of it is crude, some jokey, some so obviously fake that it could never be expected to be seen as real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: ‘Sugar’ Actress Kirby on the Only Album She Really Needs
description: She co-starred in the Apple TV+ show with Colin Farrell after appearing in “Killing Eve” and “Barry.” Now when she does a red carpet, she knows to go with Doc Martens.
content: When Kirby accepted the role of Ruby — a Bondish M-meets-Q foil to a Los Angeles private detective played by Colin Farrell — in the Apple TV+ series “Sugar,” she found herself among kindred spirits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Sam Butcher, Who Gave the World Precious Moments, Dies at 85
description: His childlike porcelain characters thrilled and inspired generations of collectors. They also made him a millionaire.
content: Sam Butcher, the soft-spoken artist whose doe-eyed, pastel-hued porcelain Precious Moments figurines ignited a global collecting frenzy and made him a wealthy man, and whose Christian faith spurred him to build his own version of the Sistine Chapel in Carthage, Mo., died on May 20 at his home there. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

title: That Other Guy
description: People tethered to a particular someone else, whether they like it or not.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: They’re Asian. They’re American. But, They Wonder, Are They Asian American?
description: Bhutanese Americans are the newest citizens of Asian descent. But many do not identify strongly as Asian Americans, reflecting the complexity of the label.
content: When Dinesh Nepal first arrived in the United States in 2010, he had never heard of the term “Asian American.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German Soccer Team’s Deal With a Weapons Maker Prompts Some Boos
description: For some fans of Borussia Dortmund, an advertising deal with Rheinmetall, a major arms manufacturer, has overshadowed the run-up to the Champions League final on Saturday.
content: Borussia Dortmund, one of Germany’s most successful soccer clubs, is rooted in the industrial Ruhr region and prides itself on retaining its working-class roots, community engagement and anti-establishment mentality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Richard Fausset
title: How Trump’s Most Loyal Supporters Are Responding to the Verdict
description: Many saw in the jury’s finding a rejection of themselves, of their values and even of democracy itself.
content: The sense of grievance erupted as powerfully as the verdict itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: He’s Obsessed With Sports and Politics. His Novels Are, Too.
description: Joseph O’Neill’s fiction incorporates his real-world interests in ways that can surprise even him. His latest novel, “Godwin,” is about an adrift hero searching for a soccer superstar.
content: The novelist Joseph O’Neill has a good idea of his daughter’s earliest memories: being driven through the northern swath of Benin in a jeep, in hot pursuit of a (fictional) story her father himself was only beginning to understand. This is remote terrain, even for visitors who aren’t American toddlers on their first trip to West Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Richard Linklater Sees the Killer Inside Us All
description: David Marchese talks to the acclaimed director about his new film, “Hit Man,” and life’s big questions.
content: Richard Linklater’s latest movie, “Hit Man,” is a bit of a departure for the director, who has made some of the most acclaimed and influential indie films of the last 30-plus years. The movie, which stars the ascendant Glen Powell, is about a mild-mannered college professor who has a side gig with the New Orleans Police Department, setting up stings by posing as different hit men. It’s a tight, stylish and sexy thriller, with some twisted romance added in, from a filmmaker better known for the ambling rhythms and gently existential tone of beloved classics like “Dazed and Confused,” “Boyhood” and “Before Sunrise” (not to mention his great comedy “School of Rock,” which exists in a category of its own).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cristina Rivera Garza
title: Mexico’s Women Are Speaking. Will a Female President Listen?
description: Neither female front-runner in Mexico’s presidential race has proposed a strong agenda to serve the women who put them where they are today.
content: My mother was born in 1943 in a country where she was not allowed to vote. The Mexican government did not grant women the right to vote in national elections — or the right to hold public office on a national level — until Oct. 17, 1953. Now, almost 71 years later, for the first time two women are leading the race to be Mexico’s next president: Claudia Sheinbaum, who is the front-runner, and Xóchitl Gálvez. It is no small feat for a country with a longstanding and complex relationship with machismo, and where every day some 10 women or girls are killed on average.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant and Katie Robertson
title: Google’s A.I. Search Leaves Publishers Scrambling
description: Since Google overhauled its search engine, publishers have tried to assess the danger to their brittle business models while calling for government intervention.
content: When Frank Pine searched Google for a link to a news article two months ago, he encountered paragraphs generated by artificial intelligence about the topic at the top of his results. To see what he wanted, he had to scroll past them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Grace Ashford
title: Doctor-Assisted Death Is Legal in 10 States. Could New York Be No. 11?
description: Activists have renewed attention on legislation related to the emotional issue of so-called medical aid in dying that has long languished in Albany.
content: The sounds of protest came forcefully from the Assembly chamber gallery, the chants echoing the words emblazoned on handmade banners that were held aloft: “Stop the suffering, pass the bill!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: How a Retirement Withdrawal Can Lead to a Perjury Conviction
description: A prominent lawyer was recently sentenced to home confinement for falsely claiming hardship to withdraw funds. How desperate must you be to take money out?
content: Sometimes, it’s illegal to spend money that you set aside for yourself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Bacon, Banter and the Business of a Diner
description: “I try to make people feel good.” How one New Jersey diner keeps the doors open.
content: Just after 5 a.m. on a recent Friday, Bendix Diner, a small, family-run business, began frying up eggs on the griddle to make the first of dozens of dishes it would serve to a steadily rotating cast of regulars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: He Could Be the Next Lionel Messi. If Anyone Can Find Him.
description: In Joseph O’Neill’s new novel, the search for an African sports prodigy is wrapped around a story of American workplace dysfunction.
content: It’s possible that you have encountered someone like Mark Wolfe, a restive 40-something in Pittsburgh who has, in his own words, “not fully recovered from a decade spent as an active member of the American intelligentsia.” Maybe you’ve worked with this guy, slept with him, sparred with him on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: The History of Black Baseball Players, on Full Display
description: As the number of African American players dwindles, a new exhibit at the Hall of Fame traces 150 years of Black baseball feats, stars and obstacles.
content: Octavius Catto’s impact was mostly unknown here at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, amid the sport’s heroic feats of lore and legend, like Joe DiMaggio’s 56-game hit streak, Ted Williams’s .406 batting average and Hank Aaron’s 715th home run to break Babe Ruth’s record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Maggie Haberman
title: New York, Once Trump’s Playground, Is Now the Scene of His Indignities
description: Donald J. Trump was for decades a creature of New York. But in recent years, the city that helped make him seems more eager to break him.
content: New York City was once Donald J. Trump’s playground, the place where he made his name and then plastered it everywhere he could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Notre-Dame Rises Again ... in Lego
description: With rose windows, bell towers and a central spire, this model of the famed Paris cathedral is all the hype among adult fans of Lego, known as AFOLs.
content: Arnaud Gaudillat, a history teacher in France, recalled bursting into tears as he watched television coverage of flames tearing through the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in 2019. “We couldn’t do anything but just watch it burn,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucinda Rosenfeld
title: She Dreamed of a New York Media Life. Would Her Soul Survive It?
description: In “Ambition Monster,” Jennifer Romolini recounts a rise from blue-collar dropout to “Corporate Barbie,” and what it cost her.
content: This spring, the website LitHub published an essay about the lack of financial particulars in contemporary fiction. That piece stayed in my head as I read Jennifer Romolini’s spirited memoir about her transformation from an angry and self-destructive child of teen parents in working-class Philadelphia to a hard-charging fashion magazine editor and, later, a “Corporate Barbie” at a Fortune 500 tech company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: Worried About Youth Crime, Newark Revives an 11 P.M. Curfew
description: Newark has begun enforcing a longstanding law that prohibits people under 18 from being out late at night.
content: When officials in Newark noted a recent increase in violent crime in their city, they were especially concerned about teenagers, both as perpetrators and as victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Rolls Back A.I. Search Feature After Flubs and Flaws
description: Google appears to have turned off its new A.I. Overviews for a number of searches as it works to minimize errors.
content: When Sundar Pichai, Google’s chief executive, introduced a generative artificial intelligence feature for the company’s search engine last month, he and his colleagues demonstrated the new capability with six text-based queries that the public could try out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Scandals and Missteps Slow Momentum of Germany’s Far Right
description: The Alternative for Germany party remains strong, but a growing pushback at home and abroad may be blunting its surge.
content: The far-right Alternative for Germany party was poised for a banner year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump and Allies Assail Conviction With Faulty Claims
description: After former President Donald J. Trump was found guilty, he and a number of conservative figures in the news media and lawmakers on the right have spread false and misleading claims about the Manhattan case.
content: After former President Donald J. Trump was found guilty of all 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, he instantly rejected the verdict and assailed the judge and criminal justice system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: South African Voters Reject the Party That Freed Them From Apartheid
description: The African National Congress received less than 50 percent of the national vote for the first time since gaining power 30 years ago, setting the nation on an uncharted course.
content: The African National Congress lost its political monopoly on South Africa after election results on Saturday showed that with almost all of the votes counted, the party had received only about 40 percent, falling short of winning an absolute majority for the first time since vanquishing Africa’s last white-led regime 30 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan Gelgud
title: Elaine May, Ahead of Her Time
description: For the brilliant comedian, writer and director, Hollywood success was elusive. A new book offers perspective on the rocky career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,079, June 2, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Eileen Sullivan
title: A 9/11 Charity Provides a Financial Safety Net to a Giuliani Firm
description: Five months after filing for bankruptcy, the former New York City mayor disclosed his company’s income from a foundation established to honor a firefighter killed on Sept. 11, 2001.
content: Because of his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, Rudolph W. Giuliani has been indicted in two states and hit with a $148 million defamation judgment that forced him to seek bankruptcy protection.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Fresh From a Title, Hayes Takes Over the National Team
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 1, 2024.
content: “I’m lucky to be born in England, but made in America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Biden Dons Kansas City Helmet to Celebrate Its Super Bowl Victory
description: Taylor Swift was not at the White House to celebrate with her boyfriend, Travis Kelce, but kicker Harrison Butker, who recently drew controversy for a commencement speech, attended.
content: On Friday, President Biden urgently called for an end to the war in Gaza. He solemnly discussed the rule of law after former President Donald J. Trump’s criminal conviction. And he donned a shiny red helmet to the whoops and cheers of a pack of football players and fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger
title: ‘2,000 Mules’ Producer Apologizes to Man Depicted Committing Election Fraud
description: Salem Media Group, which co-produced the 2022 film, issued the apology to a Georgia man who was falsely depicted as stuffing a ballot box near Atlanta.
content: The conservative media company Salem Media Group has apologized to a Georgia man who was falsely depicted as having committed election fraud in the film “2,000 Mules,” which Salem co-produced and released in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Ohio Legislature Passes Bill Ensuring Biden’s Spot on the Ballot
description: The bill, which Gov. Mike DeWine, a Republican, is expected to sign this weekend, appeared to end the possibility that President Biden would not be on the state’s ballot in November.
content: The Ohio General Assembly has passed a legislative fix that ensures President Biden will be on the state’s ballot in November, averting a crisis that had been brewing for weeks over what is typically a minor procedural issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Meet Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore, the NASA Astronauts Riding on Boeing’s Starliner
description: After a May 6 liftoff was scrubbed, the astronauts returned to their home base in Houston and continued their preparations for Saturday’s flight.
content: For Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, the wait for this trip on the Boeing Starliner has been longer than they expected.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 1, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 1, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about the new president of Yale University misstated the number of  votes cast against a Stony Brook faculty senate motion to censure Maurie McInnis. It was 55, not 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: ‘Everyone Sat Stunned After the First Bite’
description: Chez Panisse’s blueberry cobbler has that effect.
content: A confession: I almost always pull back the sugar in a dessert recipe. (I’m sharing this here because I don’t think I’m alone.) I do this because 1) I come from a home where “not too sweet” is the highest praise a dessert can get; 2) I get cavities just by thinking about sweets; and 3) I love, love, love fresh fruit, and the last thing I want to do to my perfect, beautiful, expensive farmers’ market finds is dull their bright personalities with heaps of sugar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Has Few Ways to Overturn His Conviction as a New York Felon
description: The judge in Donald J. Trump’s case closed off many avenues of appeal, experts said, though his lawyers might challenge the novel theory at the case’s center.
content: “This is long from over,” Donald J. Trump, the former president and current felon, declared on Thursday, moments after a Manhattan jury convicted him on 34 counts of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucia Buricelli
title: Scenes From a Historic Verdict
description: A photographer captured the crowds outside the courthouse during Trump’s trial — and as the historic verdict came down.
content: In recent weeks, the scene outside the criminal courthouse in Downtown Manhattan where former President Donald Trump was standing trial was one of relatively orderly anticipation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: As Voting Ends in India, Modi Awaits a Verdict on His 10 Years in Power
description: While a newly united opposition seemed to gain some traction, exit polls showed the popular and entrenched prime minister was winning a third term.
content: Voting in India’s general election, a six-week-long referendum on Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s decade in power, came to a close on Saturday as much of the country’s populous north was gripped by a deadly heat wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Security Deposits: Your Landlord May Owe You More Than You Think
description: Landlords are required to put security deposits in interest-bearing bank accounts. How much of that interest goes to you?
content: Q: I live in a large market-rate apartment building on the Upper West Side. My landlord placed my security deposit in an interest-bearing account, as required by law. The account only pays 1 percent and the bank sends the full interest earnings to my landlord each month as a fee permitted by New York state. However, at the end of the year, I received a 1099 for the interest earned even though I never received the funds. Is this legal? And isn’t the landlord obligated to put the deposit in a higher-earning account considering that any earnings above 1 percent go to me?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 2, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 2, 2024.
content: An article on June 2 about student protests at Columbia University misstates the date that the university’s president, Minouche Shafik, asked the New York City Police Department to clear a pro-Palestinian student encampment on the university’s lawn. It was April 18, not April 17. The article also misstates the position of the literary theorist and activist Edward Said on a two-state solution. He supported the proposal in the 1990s but changed his public stance to support a one-state solution later in that decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: How Rhubarb Conquered Germany, Then the World
description: A tongue-twisting rap by a Berlin duo has spotlighted Germans’ love of their springtime produce. Now if only they could find a rhyme for asparagus.
content: In the past month, millions of people have found themselves stumbling through the contorted and catchy syllables of a song about, of all things, a woman named Barbara and some rhubarb-loving barbarians who drink beer while getting their beards barbered. In German.
source.name: The New York Times
